1 cup of Milk Powder 1/4 cup of All-Purpose Flour (Maida) 1/4 cup of Ghee (clarified butter) A pinch of Baking Soda 2-3 tablespoons of Milk (for kneading) A few drops of Rose Water (optional, for flavor)
For Sugar Syrup:
1.5 cups of Sugar 1.5 cups of Water A few Saffron strands (optional) 1/2 teaspoon of Cardamom Powder 1 teaspoon of Rose Water For Frying:
Ghee or Oil for deep frying Instructions:
Making Sugar Syrup:
In a saucepan, add sugar and water. Bring it to a boil, stirring occasionally, until the sugar dissolves completely.
Add saffron strands (if using) and cardamom powder to the syrup. Simmer the syrup for about 5-7 minutes until it slightly thickens. Keep it warm and set aside.
Preparing Gulab Jamun Dough:
In a mixing bowl, combine milk powder, all-purpose flour, baking soda, and ghee.
Mix everything well. The mixture will resemble breadcrumbs.
Gradually add a few tablespoons of milk and start kneading the mixture into a smooth and soft dough. The dough should be soft but not sticky. If it's too dry, add a little more milk, and if it's too sticky, add a bit more milk powder.
Divide the dough into small equal-sized portions and roll them into smooth, crack-free balls. Ensure there are no cracks, or else the Gulab Jamuns may break while frying.
Frying Gulab Jamun:
Heat ghee or oil in a deep frying pan over medium-low heat. To check if the oil is ready, drop a small piece of dough into the oil; it should sizzle and rise slowly without changing color too quickly.
Carefully slide a few Gulab Jamun balls into the hot oil. Fry them on low to medium-low heat, stirring gently and consistently to ensure even browning. Fry until they turn golden brown. This should take about 7-10 minutes.
Remove the fried Gulab Jamun balls using a slotted spoon and drain excess oil.
Soaking Gulab Jamun:
Immediately place the hot Gulab Jamuns into the warm sugar syrup. Let them soak for at least 1-2 hours so that they absorb the syrup and become soft and juicy.
Serve the Gulab Jamun warm or at room temperature. You can garnish them with chopped nuts if desired.
Enjoy your homemade Gulab Jamun! They are best when served warm, and they make for a delightful dessert at festivals and special occasions.
